content.description: Start sitting, almost on your back underneath the small overhanging arete. Begin with a solid heel, and hold it until you've securely slapped up the razor's edge.  Stick in there and hold strong as your bad feet need your good hands to finish off this small boulder.
content.protection: A pad, can be done alone.
content.location: This is the first of a group of tiny boulder off to your right, just as you hit the area.  There's some nice sand if your pad isn't enough too. It's a sharp, dark colored arete.

content.description: Difficulty increases along with commitment as you approach the top out on this climb.  Move left and up while hanging through five or six moves, then reach for a good left pull then crimpers on the mantle.  Have fun on this one. My favorite at the Lower Wash.
content.protection: At least two pads and a spotter to keep you off the rock below.
content.location: After the main group of boulders below the bridge, the wash veers left and you'd be blind to miss Jabba on your right.  One big awesome blob of a boulder.  Scale the side that faces the wash next to the large fallen dead tree.

content.description: Get yourself onto the bump at the bottom then use some hands in the crack to get a couple moves up. There's a few nice holds at the top but it's a bit scary of a top out without a spotter.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter.
content.location: The Boxing Glove faces you as you reach the climbs. It's at the back left and is shaped like a boxing glove, obviously. Two cracks split its face and it's got a sandy color.

content.description: Great bouldering all year round, well, at least as much as you bad little self can handle.
